title: Heterosexual couple lose legal battle to enter civil partnership
text:
Heterosexual couple lose legal battle over British civil partnership law Paul Lawlor Updated 1041 GMT (1841 HKT) February 21, 2017 
Chat with us in Facebook Messenger. Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds. Charles Keidan and Rebecca Steinfeld outside the High Court in London. (CNN) A heterosexual couple in Britain have lost their court battle for the right to enter into a civil partnership -- an alternative to marriage that is reserved for same-sex couples in the UK. The Court of Appeal in London rejected a claim by Rebecca Steinfeld and Charles Keidan, who argued they were discriminated against because civil partnerships are not available to people of the opposite sex. Steinfeld and Keidan oppose traditional marriage because they regard it as a "patriarchal" institution. Speaking outside court, Steinfeld said they were "deeply disappointed" by the ruling. The 2004 Civil Partnership Act allowed same-sex couples in Britain to enter a legal partnership for the first time. It conferred almost the same legal rights as traditional marriage, except for the right to marry in a religious setting. Same-sex civil partners did not have the right to declare themselves "married" for legal purposes. Britain legalized same-sex marriage in 2013, but retained civil partnership legislation. Read More Steinfeld and Keidan had argued in lower court hearings that the provisions around civil partnership were "incompatible with equality law." The government argued that it would make a final decision on whether to abolish civil partnerships or extend them to everyone after evaluating the impact of the later same-sex marriage law. Two of the three judges hearing the case at the Court of Appeal said the government should have more time to evaluate the best way forward on civil partnerships and marriages. The third judge dissented, according to a summary of the judgment released by the Court of Appeal.
